27.72.text: Hello. Another bout of intellectual Buckaroo lies ahead of us tonight

32.24.text: as we play the last of the first-round matches

36.28.text: So far, Magdalen College, Oxford and the universities of Manchester

39.44.text: and Sheffield have earned themselves places in the semifinals.

43.08.text: If tonight's winners are to go through and join them,

45.36.text: they need to beat University College London's score of 155.

49.48.text: Now, first tonight, the team from the University of Durham.

52.48.text: We pride ourselves on this programme that this series is one of the few

55.44.text: occasions when librarians get the recognition they deserve,

58.60.text: and Durham's first team member has worked in the libraries

62.32.text: of the House of Lords and Edinburgh University,

64.48.text: as well as the National Library of Scotland.

66.92.text: He is the 25th incumbent of his current post,

72.32.text: With him, a news presenter and reporter who,

74.92.text: in the past 20 years, has covered stories both in studio

78.08.text: and on location, from the crisis in Ukraine

80.68.text: to the rescue of the Chilean miners,

82.88.text: the uprisings of the Arab spring and the Japanese tsunami.

86.96.text: Their captain is a leading space scientist.

89.72.text: She has headed the Meteorite team at the Natural History Museum

93.24.text: and in 2014 she was the world's cheerleader when the Philae probe

97.24.text: became the first spacecraft to land on a comet nucleus.

101.04.text: Joining them is a Dutch-born entrepreneur

103.40.text: who in 2000 founded an institution which has attracted 16 million

107.76.text: visitors and brought over £1 billion into the Cornish economy.

115.28.text: I graduated from Durham in 1985, in modern history and economic history.

120.08.text: I'm now Bodley's Librarian, which means I'm responsible

122.88.text: for the research libraries of the University of Oxford.

126.76.text: I'm Tim Willcox. I read Spanish at Durham

130.56.text: Since then, I've been working as a journalist in newspapers then TV.

134.12.text: I currently work as a presenter for BBC News.

140.28.text: I read chemistry and geology at St Aidan's College, Durham,

144.84.text: I'm currently Professor of Planetary and Space Sciences

149.84.text: My name is Tim Smit. I graduated in 1976 from Durham,

155.72.text: But today I lead the Eden Project

157.92.text: and the Lost Gardens of Heligan in Cornwall.

165.92.text: Their opponents are playing for the London School of Economics.

168.96.text: Its founders in 1895 included Sidney and Beatrice Webb

172.16.text: and George Bernard Shaw, and the four trying not to let them down

175.64.text: tonight include a former criminal law barrister turned Conservative MP.

180.32.text: He's been Shadow Minister for London, local government minister

185.12.text: With him, a journalist who has spent eight years as the

189.92.text: He left that job to take up his present role, of

192.64.text: which he said that it was "the only one that could have lured him away -

195.92.text: "and if it goes wrong, he'll be on the next plane back."

199.44.text: Their captain is an award-winning campaigner, newspaper columnist,

203.16.text: and writer on all things to do with personal finances.

206.20.text: He presents his own programme on ITV,

208.12.text: is the resident expert on numerous other programmes,

210.92.text: and is executive chairman of the UK's biggest money website.

215.08.text: Their fourth team member began his career as one of the youngest

218.40.text: show business editors in Fleet Street.

220.60.text: Since then he's written for the Times Literary Supplement

223.28.text: and The Guardian, but is best known for presenting numerous radio

226.60.text: and television programmes. Let's meet the LSE team.

230.24.text: Hi, I'm Bob Neill. I read law at LSE in the 1970s.

233.88.text: Now I'm the MP for Bromley and Chislehurst

236.40.text: and Chair of Parliament's Justice Select Committee.

241.40.text: I took a degree in economics in 1983.

243.96.text: Now I present the Today programme on Radio Four.

249.32.text: I graduated in government and law in 1994.

252.44.text: I've since founded and run moneysavingexpert.com.

255.92.text: This is Felix, the LSE Beaver.

261.00.text:
- with a gift for double entendre. 
- LAUGHTER

263.88.text: Hello, I'm James O'Brien. I graduated in 1995

269.60.text: I'm now a journalist and broadcaster with a daily show on LBC radio.

278.12.text: OK, you all know the rules, I guess. If you don't, you shouldn't be here.

282.00.text: So let's just crack on with it, shall we?

284.36.text: Fingers on the buzzers, here's your first starter for ten.

288.72.text: what six-letter adjective may proceed the words

291.72.text: stick, bean, horn, cricket, mustard, dressing, toast...?

301.68.text: Right, Durham. Your bonuses are on a work of literature.

307.16.text: Which short novel of 1843 did the Illustrated London News note -

311.00.text: "the surpassing beauty with which they accomplished

314.00.text: "author of this seasonable little volume has worked out - or,

317.32.text: "as he supportively terms it, raised 'the ghost of an idea'"?

325.28.text: After reading A Christmas Carol, which notoriously

330.44.text: and essayist was seized with a perfect convulsion of hospitality

335.20.text: and hosted two festive dinner parties at his Cheyne Walk residence?

342.92.text: To which character in a Christmas Carol

346.56.text: he wrote, "There is not a reader in England but that little creature will

349.88.text: "be a bond of union between the author and him"?

362.00.text: formerly attributed to Dionysius the Aeropagite,

365.36.text: was an important influence on which 13th-century theologian?

371.28.text: his works included the Summa Theologica.

378.64.text: Your bonuses are on Jewish religious festivals, Durham.

382.00.text: Originally an agricultural festival marking the start of the summer

385.96.text: wheat harvest, Shavuot, or the Festival of the Weeks,

389.60.text: is also known by what name, from the Greek meaning 50th?

404.32.text: Translated into English as the Feast of Lots, which festival

407.88.text: commemorates the survival of the Jews who, according to the Book of Esther,

411.92.text: were marked for death by the Persian rulers in the 5th century BC?

423.48.text: And finally, thought to derive from the Hebrew verb meaning to dedicate,

426.88.text: what name denotes the festival celebrated over eight days,

429.92.text: and also known as the Feast of Dedication,

432.44.text: the Feast of Lights and the Feast of the Maccabees?

437.36.text:
- Hanukkah. 
- Correct. Ten points for this.

439.72.text: Who was the subject of Andrew Robinson's 2006 biography

443.04.text: entitled The Last Man Who Knew Everything?

445.56.text: A physician and physicist born in Somerset in 1773,

449.16.text: he established the principle of interference of light,

452.12.text: and was instrumental in deciphering the Rosetta Stone.

462.68.text: Your bonuses are on scientific theories later disproved, Durham.

469.32.text: an early chemical theory assumed that all combustible material

472.68.text: was in part composed of which hypothetical substance?

476.24.text: The idea was discredited by Lavoisier from 1770.

480.92.text: Correct. What name was given to the weightless, transparent,

483.92.text: frictionless substance thought to permeate all matter and space,

487.20.text: until the Michelson-Morley experiment of 1881 severely

490.40.text: weakened the theory of its existence.

493.88.text: Correct. And finally, work by Wegener in 1912 was the first rigorous

499.08.text: attempt to refute the idea that the major landmasses of the Earth were

502.84.text: immovable. This view persisted until the 1960s,

506.20.text: when what theory became generally accepted?

510.48.text: Or continental drift, yes. Right, a picture round now.

514.88.text: you are going to see a map showing

516.80.text: the locations of the host venues

522.12.text: For ten points, I want you to

533.36.text: It is the ICC Cricket World Cup. Well done.

538.48.text: For your picture bonuses, you'll see three of those cities highlighted.

542.16.text: For five points each, I want you to identify the city

545.08.text: and the name of its cricket ground at which World Cup matches were played.

549.20.text: Firstly, the city and cricket ground at A.

563.08.text: It is Brisbane. It's the Gabba though, the cricket ground.

565.84.text: Secondly, the city and the cricket ground at B.

572.60.text: Do we know the cricket ground at Auckland?

576.12.text: Auckland and the Auckland Cricket Ground.

581.36.text: And finally, the city and cricket ground at C.

585.80.text:
- That's Sydney, isn't it? 
- The MCC. Or is it Melbourne?

595.64.text: It's Melbourne and the MCG. The Melbourne Cricket Ground.

599.40.text: Oh, actually, you can have it. Why not?

605.36.text: The History Of A Dangerous Idea is the subtitle of which

608.16.text: recent work by the British political economist Mark Blyth?

611.48.text: The single-word title denotes a particular approach to

623.84.text: Three questions on carol singing for your bonuses, LSE.

626.64.text: In each case, give the title of the literary work

628.92.text: from which the following lines are taken.

633.16.text: "There had been singing under the windows after midnight -

638.68.text: "in spite of Tom's contemptuous insistence that the singers

642.16.text: "were Old Patch, the parish clerk, and the rest of the church choir."

648.84.text: No, it's from The Mill On The Floss by George Eliot.

653.44.text: "For a year we had praised the Lord, out of key,

656.64.text: "and as a reward for this service we now had the right to visit

660.20.text: "all the big houses, to sing our carols and collect our tribute."

674.24.text: That's from Cider With Rosie by Laurie Lee.

676.20.text: And finally, from a 1908 novel for children.

678.52.text: "As the door opened, one of the elder ones that carried

681.52.text: "the lantern was just saying, 'Now then - one, two, three!'

684.76.text: "And forthwith their shrill little voices uprose on the air

687.88.text: "singing one of the old-time carols that their forefathers composed."

696.80.text:
- No, it's The Wind In The Willows. 
- Wind In The Willows!

699.20.text: Ten points for this. Listen carefully.

701.20.text: Benjamin Disraeli described idiosyncrasy is a quality

703.80.text: "which ought never to be possessed by an Archbishop of Canterbury,

708.36.text: What is the dictionary spelling of the word idiosyncrasy?

739.72.text: So, ten points at stake for this starter question.

742.64.text: Harvest Of The Cold Months - The Social History Of Ice And Ices

747.48.text: is a later work by which author, who died in 1992?

750.88.text: Perhaps best-known for French provincial cooking,

754.00.text: she has been described as "the best writer on food and drink..."

763.20.text: LSE, you get questions on Iris Murdoch and philosophy.

767.52.text: "People were liberated by that book after the war,

770.24.text: "it made people happy, it was like the Gospel."

773.08.text: These words of Iris Murdoch referred to Being And Nothingness,

776.92.text: a work by which French philosopher?

786.32.text: Correct. Iris Murdoch's 1977 work The Fire And The Sun discusses the

791.16.text: attitude to art and the theory of beauty of which ancient philosopher?

800.80.text: Plato seems more likely, doesn't he?

805.08.text: In the 1959 essay The Sublime And The Good,

807.76.text: what concept did Iris Murdoch described as "the extremely

811.12.text: "difficult realisation that something other than oneself is real"?

825.24.text: Which three cautionary words link a 1968 recording by the sound

829.36.text: engineer Peter Lodge, the voice artist Emma Clarke, and The Archers

833.28.text: actor Tim Bentinck, who has been heard on the Piccadilly Line?

843.20.text: Right, three questions on checkmates in chess for your bonuses, LSE.

847.40.text: Scholar's mate is a checkmate that may often catch out a beginner,

850.76.text: and always results in a win after how many moves?

859.76.text:
- Six or eight. 
- I think it's three.

868.40.text: No, it's four. It's also known as the four-move checkmate.

872.92.text: Involving a queen with a bishop, checkmating the opposing king.

878.20.text: what term describes a checkmate by knight against a king that

881.96.text: has all of its escape squares blocked by its own pieces?

885.80.text: The term suggests being surrounded and unable to breathe.

898.08.text: And finally, Anastasia's mate and Arabian mate most commonly involve

902.92.text: which two pieces working in tandem to checkmate the opposing king?

906.68.text: It would be a horse, wouldn't it?

913.24.text: No, it's a knight and a rook.

915.48.text: Right, we are going to take a music round now.

917.60.text: For your music starter, you'll hear a piece of popular music.

920.20.text: Ten points if you can identify the artist, please.

938.84.text: # Look at yourselves in a ghost town... #

945.44.text: It doesn't sound anything like Adele.

947.60.text: I've got no idea. And nobody else seems to have.

950.36.text: Well, it was enterprising of you to have a go.

952.32.text: You are wrong, I'm afraid though.

954.00.text: Anyone like to buzz from the LSE?

959.64.text: No, it's Madonna. It's Ghost Town.

961.84.text: Music bonuses in a moment or two.

963.56.text: Ten points at stake for this starter question.

966.24.text: In which sensory organ of the human body are the specialised cells

973.00.text: They form part of the surface of the vitreous body.

982.92.text: Right, you will recall that Madonna fell over on stage at the 2015

986.88.text: Brit Awards due to an unfortunate entanglement of her costume.

990.68.text: For your bonuses, you are going to hear three more songs by groups

993.84.text: or artists who experienced similar onstage calamities in 2015.

998.28.text: Firstly for five, can you to identify this band?

1008.32.text:
- # One in ten... # 
- Ace Of Spades...

1011.28.text: # Don't want to be your monkey wrench... #

1018.44.text: The lead singer and guitarist, Dave Grohl,

1020.60.text: broke his leg falling off stage in Gothenburg.

1023.28.text: Secondly, can you name this artist, please?

1027.44.text:
- # Uh-huh, yeah 
- It's all about the Benjamins, baby

1040.12.text: No, it's Puff Daddy, or P Diddy, or Diddy, or Puffy, or Sean Combs...

1045.48.text: ..who fell into a hole during an awards ceremony, apparently.

1048.52.text: Finally, I specifically want the name or nickname

1051.76.text: of the guitarist of this band.

1062.68.text: It is The Edge. Yes. Who fell off the edge, apparently. In Vancouver.

1068.44.text: Which two initial letters link words meaning the process of

1077.08.text: No. I'm sorry, you are wrong. You lose five points too.

1079.96.text: ..a short pastoral poem - for example, by Virgil -

1085.44.text: and the study of living things within their environment.

1097.72.text: I'm not going to recite the long list of terms involved.

1101.68.text: Which small city in North Dakota shares its name with

1104.00.text: a film of 1996 with the tag line -

1106.28.text: Small town. Big crime. Dead cold?

1109.04.text: It start Frances McDormand and was...

1116.48.text: Your bonuses this time are on astronomy,

1120.72.text: All three answers contain the letter combination DNA.

1124.56.text: Discovered in 2003, which trans-Neptunian object was

1128.40.text: given a five-letter name after an Inuit goddess of the sea?

1141.96.text: Secondly, founded in the late 18th century, which government-owned

1145.44.text: company's products include the Explorer and the Landranger series?

1161.40.text: And finally, born with the surname Beazley,

1164.56.text: who was created a Dame in 1974?

1167.36.text: The creation was portrayed as a spontaneous

1170.32.text: gesture by the Australian Prime Minister Gough Whitlam.

1178.64.text: You are quite right. It is Edna Everage, yes.

1182.48.text: Right, ten points at stake for this.

1184.28.text: Meanings of what six-letter word include either of the

1187.32.text: two pendulous, fleshy growths on each side of a turkey's beak,

1197.76.text: Your bonuses, Durham, are on mnemonics.

1200.80.text: Will A Jolly Man Make A Jolly Visitor is a mnemonic for the surnames

1205.80.text: of the first eight US presidents.

1208.32.text: Which two presidents are represented by the phrase Jolly Man?

1225.04.text: How shocking! Tom's Songs Make Me Queasy

1228.48.text: is a mnemonic for the names of the major Chinese dynasties,

1233.24.text: Which dynasty does the word Queasy represent?

1235.72.text: You may spell it if you wish.

1241.96.text: Correct. No Plan Like Yours To Study History Wisely

1246.24.text: is a mnemonic for the royal houses of England, beginning with the Norman.

1250.32.text: For which houses do the words Like Yours stand?

1259.48.text: Correct. The winner takes a second picture round now.

1263.12.text: you are going to see a photograph of a theatrical production.

1265.80.text: The ten points, I want you to identify both the actor you see

1269.20.text: and the role he is playing.

1282.32.text: which has become the fastest-selling play in London theatre history.

1286.00.text: Your picture bonuses show three more 2015 record breakers.

1290.84.text: I want you to identify the subject of this exhibition.

1304.96.text: His exhibition Savage Beauty broke the V&A's attendance record.

1308.76.text: Secondly, the title of this painting.

1310.68.text: You can give it in either English or French.

1315.52.text: I don't know the name of the painting.

1321.60.text: No, it's the Women Of Algiers by Picasso.

1323.92.text: The most expensive artwork sold at auction.

1327.04.text: Finally, I want you to identify this film, please.

1331.36.text:
- I don't know. 
- Not a clue.

1333.56.text: It's all been record breakers. Was there something huge this year?

1345.64.text: No, it's Jurassic World. In June 2015, it broke the record

1349.16.text: for the most successful global opening weekend.

1353.64.text: In October 2015, who led the Liberal Party to an unexpected

1357.00.text: victory in the Canadian federal election?

1365.32.text: Right, your bonuses this time, LSE, are on memorials.

1368.68.text: William Wyggeston and Simon De Montfort are two of the four

1371.92.text: men represented by statues on the Haymarket Memorial Clock Tower

1381.20.text: Designed by George Gilbert Scott, the Martyrs' Memorial on St Giles'

1384.96.text: in Oxford commemorates the three men known as the Oxford martyrs.

1388.92.text: Thomas Cranmer was one. Name either of the other two.

1398.88.text: Can you settle down with your buzzers there?

1401.12.text: LAUGHTER The other one was Latimer.

1405.16.text: the National Memorial Arboretum is located close to the River Tame,

1409.24.text: a tributary of the Trent, in which English county?

1421.60.text: Equilibrium Points In n-Person Games was the title of the ground-breaking

1426.40.text: paper of 1949 by which US mathematician, who died in May 2015?

1435.84.text: Level pegging. You get these bonuses, they'll give you the lead.

1438.92.text: They are on the Stirling Prize for Architecture.

1441.12.text: The media centre at which UK sporting venue won

1447.08.text: It was the world's first all-aluminium,

1452.68.text: Correct. The 2014 prize went to the architects of the rebuilding of which

1460.96.text: in the shell of a 19th-century chapel.

1473.04.text: It was the Everyman Theatre. And finally,

1475.12.text: the restoration of Astley Castle, a ruined manor house,

1478.60.text: won its architects the Stirling Prize in 2013.

1481.60.text: It is situated to the south-west of Nuneaton in which English county?

1487.40.text:
- Leicester. 
- Or was it Warwickshire? Worcestershire.

1495.00.text: SHE SIGHS Ten points for this. Born in 1830,

1498.40.text: Emily Davies was a pioneer of higher education for women and a founder

1502.24.text: of which institution, named after a village north-west of Cambridge?

1512.00.text: Your bonuses, LSE, are on a London museum.

1514.80.text: William Hogarth's A Rake's Progress is part of the collection

1518.24.text: of which museum in Lincoln's Inn Fields,

1520.76.text: named after the Regency architect who left it to the nation in 1837?

1528.40.text: Part of the Soane Collection, what event is the subject of a series

1531.60.text: of paintings by Hogarth inspired by the Oxfordshire contest of 1754?

1536.44.text: It depicts vicious indulgence in sensual pleasures, the wearing

1540.92.text: of blue or orange ribbons, and the distribution of bribes.

1551.48.text: It's not the polling or something like that. It's...

1556.28.text: It's something to do with elections. Is it the polling?

1559.32.text: I'll accept that, yes. It's The Humours Of An Election.

1562.24.text: A general or parliamentary election, yes.

1564.72.text: Also in the Soane Collection, Les Noces, or The Marriage,

1567.64.text: is a work of the 1710s by which artist, born in Valenciennes,

1571.64.text: a major exponent of the genre known as fetes galantes?

1584.12.text: Ten points for this. Listen carefully.

1586.12.text: For what does the letter S stand in the scientific acronym laser?

1595.28.text: Stimulated. I'll accept that. You've got the right idea.

1600.72.text: Right, your bonuses are on fictional doctors.

1603.60.text: The former Nazi, Dr Christian Szell,

1613.44.text: refers to the image of the eyes of Dr TJ Ekelberg?

1628.20.text: Right, at the gong, it's absolutely level pegging.

1631.16.text: The way we are going to sort this out now is

1633.52.text: I'm going to ask you a starter question.

1636.44.text: If you get it right, you get ten points and immediately win.

1639.68.text: If you interrupt incorrectly and get it wrong...

1645.00.text: ..you are fined five points and you automatically lose.

1649.88.text: Listen up then. Fingers on the buzzers.

1652.04.text: Cat And Mouse and Dog Years are novels in the Danzig trilogy by which

1656.68.text: German Nobel laureate who died in 2015?

1660.08.text: The first work in the trilogy is his 1959 debut novel, The Tin Drum.

1667.64.text: Gunter Grass is correct. That means you win.

1677.72.text: Well, I thought you were going to do it, LSE,

1680.12.text: but you need to bone up a bit on one or two subjects, I think.

1686.20.text: I'm afraid although you have won on 140 points, it is

1689.00.text: not one of the four highest winning scores.

1692.16.text: So we shan't be seeing you again.

1694.24.text: It means you have the honour of winning

1696.12.text: but you don't have the possible embarrassment of having to come back.

1700.80.text: We now know the teams in the semifinal stage of the competition.

1703.52.text: They will be Magdalen College, Oxford, Manchester University,

1709.20.text: I hope you can join us next time for the first of the semifinals.

1712.16.text: Until then though, it's goodbye from the LSE.

1714.16.text:
- ALL: 
- Goodbye. 
- It's goodbye from Durham University.

1716.48.text:
- ALL: 
- Goodbye. 
- And it's goodbye from me. Goodbye.
